issues.title: The first part of this sentence is confusing
issues.author: henkvancann
issues.body:
https://github.com/WebOfTrust/ietf-cesr-proof/blob/main/draft-pfeairheller-cesr-proof.md
--- abstract

A SAD (such as an Authentic Chained Data Container (ACDC) Verifiable Credential [ACDC]) may be signed with a CESR Proof Signature and streamed alongside any other CESR content...

issues.title: 'attachment codes' are only mentioned once as a term
issues.author: henkvancann

issues.title: CBOR + MessagePack references
issues.author: henkvancann
issues.body:
https://github.com/WebOfTrust/ietf-cesr-proof/blob/main/draft-pfeairheller-cesr-proof.md#streamable-sads

JSON is clearly referenced (which versions), CBOR + MessagePack references would be good too. Which versions and from which version-numbers will it work?

issues.title: Rephrase the first sentence of this block?
issues.author: henkvancann
issues.body:
https://github.com/WebOfTrust/ietf-cesr-proof/blob/main/draft-pfeairheller-cesr-proof.md#nested-partial-signatures

CESR Proof Signatures can be used to sign as many portions of a SAD (including the entire SAD) whether the signed subsets are SADs or the self-addressing identifer (SAID) of a SAD. 


CESR Proof Signatures can be used to sign as many portions (or 'subsets') of a SAD as needed, including the entire SAD. The signed subsets are either SADs themselves or the multisig part of the / one or more* self-addressing identifers (SAID) of Self Addressing Data (SAD). 

* I don't have clue, what it needs to be, but you get the idea: pls use shorter sentences and write the concept out a bit more for better understanding ;)

issues.title: An infographic would help
issues.author: henkvancann
issues.body:
https://github.com/WebOfTrust/ietf-cesr-proof/blob/main/draft-pfeairheller-cesr-proof.md#transposable-signature-attachments

a drawing maybe says more than the words in this text block?

issues.title: SAD path language sounds like marketing?
issues.author: henkvancann
issues.body:
"This path language has a more limited scope than alternatives like JSONPtr [RFC6901] or JSONPath [JSONPath] and is therefore simpler and more compact when encoding in CESR signature attachments. SADs in CESR and therefore CESR Proof Signatures require static field ordering of all maps. The SAD path language takes advantage of this feature to allow for a base64 compatible syntax into SADs even when a SAD uses non-base64 compatible characters for field labels."


This block comes across as a clever way to sell a short-coming. 

CESR Proof Signatures require static field ordering of all maps. -> why?

"takes advantage of this feature" -> or works within the self imposed limitation?

This text block leaves question about what we throw away (e.g. extensibility?) because we're not going to create something like JSONPtr [RFC6901] or JSONPath [JSONPath].

Could you shine a light on why CESR Proof Sigs and KERI will never need the scope that the alternatives cover.

comments.author: henkvancann
comments.body:
This helps already: https://github.com/WebOfTrust/ietf-cesr-proof/blob/main/draft-pfeairheller-cesr-proof.md#alternative-pathing--query-languages 

Maybe forward refer to this paragraph?

comments.author: SmithSamuelM
comments.body:
Anything that must be signed must be serialized and that serialization must be reproducable.  This means the field ordering must be fixed. So its not a unique limitation. Given that we have fixed field ordering we can simplify pathing so its is win.
JSONPth and JsonPtr were intended for non-crypto graphic applicatioins where field ordering is not required to be fixed.


Sent from my iPad

SADs in CESR and therefore CESR Proof Signatures require static field ordering of all maps. The SAD path language takes advantage of this feature to allow for a base64 compatible syntax into SADs even when a SAD uses non-base64 compatible characters for field labels."
> 
> This block comes across as a clever way to sell a short-coming.
> 
> CESR Proof Signatures require static field ordering of all maps. -> why?
> 
> "takes advantage of this feature" -> or works within the self imposed limitation?
> 
> This text block leaves question about what we throw away (e.g. extensibility?) because we're not going to create something like JSONPtr [RFC6901] or JSONPath [JSONPath].
> 
> Could you shine a light on why CESR Proof Sigs and KERI will never need the scope that the alternatives cover.

issues.title: IANA consideration, first explain briefly what it is.
issues.author: henkvancann
issues.body:
https://github.com/WebOfTrust/ietf-cesr-proof/blob/main/draft-pfeairheller-cesr-proof.md#iana-considerations

"The Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) is a standards organization that oversees global IP address allocation, autonomous system number allocation, root zone management in the Domain Name System (DNS), media types, and other Internet Protocol-related symbols and Internet numbers."
More info: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Assigned_Numbers_Authority
